content.webTitle: Andrew Leigh on how Labor's deluge of ideas helped it lose the election

fields.headline: Andrew Leigh on how Labor's deluge of ideas helped it lose the election
fields.bodyText: Andrew Leigh spent the 2019 election campaign in part talking about making it easier for independent mechanics to service cars and for hotels to offer deals outside major travel sites. Now the former shadow assistant treasurer is candid that perhaps Labor had too many ideas – even if many were good ones. “Ensuring that voters go into the polling booth understanding the core philosophy of Labor is what counts,” he tells Guardian Australia. “You can overwhelm with detail and [that’s] certainly one of the critiques that’s been made of the last election. “If that’s correct then I’m as guilty as anyone, having produced a whole raft of policy on competition, multinational tax and the like. “So I certainly take my share of blame for our election loss. But we can’t change from being a party of policy to being a party of slogans and demonising.” The MP, no longer on the frontbench but still a shadow assistant minister, has for several years hung 10 principles of politics on his wall. They have caught the eye of the Museum of Australian Democracy, which wants a copy for its collection. The MoAD director, Daryl Karp, says the museum is always on the lookout for objects that tell a story and connect with the public, part of an effort to “rebuild trust in the processes of civic engagement … and encouraging people to be excited by democracy”. She cites previous acquisitions including Julie Bishop’s shoes, a tracksuit from John Howard, and a bicycle from Tony Abbott. Leigh’s principles include noble sentiments that Labor communications “should try to engage with the better instincts of Australia, to tell stories, make new arguments and convey fresh facts”. “When we dumb down debates and demonise our opponents, progressives lose. When we enrich the public conversation, we win.” That plea for positivity seems a bit incongruous, coming after the 2016 election which Labor almost won on the back of a negative campaign arguing the Coalition would privatise Medicare, and the 2019 election, in which Labor lost offering policies so extensive it seemed to be running as an incumbent government. “The arguments go beyond any particular election cycle,” Leigh says. “You can always tell a convincing story … about why some particular tactic might work in a certain moment of history. “But from an overall strategic standpoint the progressive side of politics is looking for opportunities to use the power of government to improve the quality of people’s lives. “I think back to Ronald Reagan, who said ‘government isn’t the solution, government is the problem’. Reagan’s demonising of the role of government and politicians was deliberate; he recognised his side … benefited when people trusted government less.” Burned by an extremely negative Coalition campaign amplifying claims Labor would introduce a death tax and falsely claiming that Labor would tax non-electric cars, another colleague who now finds himself on the backbench – Ed Husic – has proposed his version of the high road: an “armistice” on fake news. Leigh acknowledges the high road will be “tough – but the alternative is to simply become Liberal-lite”. He thinks Labor should be “witty and sharp” in making its arguments but endorses Labor leader Anthony Albanese’s direction banning MPs from calling opponents liars because it is a currency that has become “debased”. Leigh wants to make politics “a bit more gracious and a bit less aggressive”. And also – it would appear – a bit quieter. Media coverage, the 10 principles state, is “a means, not an end”. “It’s … a reminder to myself and my team that while it might be pleasing to see your name in dispatches, the main game is improving people’s lives,” Leigh says. “There’s always the risk for anyone in politics that you worry about column inches rather than about tangible improvements. “It’s often a question of whether you can achieve more quietly, internally, by collaborating with others by focusing on the outcome rather than on publicity … All of us have egos, and our challenge is to ensure our egos aren’t what’s driving things.” Leigh’s principles also aim to help keep politics human. They ask staff to “act ethically, crack jokes when we can, and keep a sense of perspective” and “don’t apologise for spending time with friends and family, exercising or reading fiction”. “Not only is socialising important in itself; a well-rounded life helps us do our jobs better. Strive for calmness, balance and gratitude.” Karp says the 10 principles are a “dynamic entry point” to understanding some of the contemporary challenges of modern politics, including the 24/7 media cycle, work-life balance, and the prevailing “combative approach” to politics. “It represents an individual setting out their values and then standing by them,” she says. “Whether it becomes a substantial historical document is unknown, but for now … it speaks to the contemporary zeitgeist of visitors and the challenges of politics.”
